Award.AwardTitle: Methods of algebraic geometry in algebraic topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to further the study of stable homotopy theory by methods and machinery developed in algebraic geometry. There are four main goals. The first goal is the study of specific examples of spectra of topological automorphic forms, focusing on computations for the Shimura curve of discriminant 15 and Picard modular surfaces at chromatic level 3. Second, joint work of Michael Hill and the PI aims to extend the theory of topological modular forms to the log-etale site of the moduli of elliptic curves, and in particular to functorially produce topological modular forms with level structure. Third, the PI hopes to further develop machinery employing Zink's theory of displays to produce highly structured multiplications on various spectra of importants in chromatic homotopy theory. Finally, joint work with David Gepner will study Picard and Brauer groups in the derived setting using recently-developed machinery in higher category theory.

The main focus of this research field is to systematically study qualitative properties of shape by methods from algebra. In the past, these methods have led to surprising connections between many disparate fields of mathematics, and developments in these fields have translated into genuine information about geometric structures which is difficult to obtain otherwise. The goal of this research project is to take some of these most recent advances, taking place in subjects like higher category theory and algebraic geometry, and develop them into concrete tools that can advance our knowledge further.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algebraic topology originated in the study of shape, and in particularly studying what properties of shapes remain the same even under small perturbations or deformations. Many geometric shapes can be decomposed into basic building blocks called cells. Many mathematical tools were developed to aid our understanding ofdifferent types of shapes in terms of how they are built up from these basic cells. Some of the most successful are called homology (which give some measure ofthe number and type of cells needed to build a shape, as well as some information about their interaction) and homotopy (which give some measure of how many different ways that new cells can be added to a shape). Homology is effectively computable in most situations, whereas homotopy is extraordinarily complex and we know complete answers in only the very simplest cases. This process is ongoing and making large strides even to this day.


In studying homotopy a number of systematic patterns and working methods began to emerge. Many of the most successful have involved constructing bridges between the world of geometry and the world of algebra, progressively reducing difficult questions to ones that can be addressed with a combination of computational resources and recognition of underlying patterns. There was a sudden influx of powerful new tools into this area in the early 2000's due to work of Elmendorff-Kriz-Mandell-May, Hovey-Shipley-Smith, and many others. One of the most prominent tools is called a structured ring spectrum: an object that captures both algebraic operations analogous to addition, subtraction, and multiplication, but also carries geometric information where the rules that these operations satisfy are only true up to perturbations or deformations. A great deal of prior work has been clarified by these developments and many technical difficulties that persistedsince the 1970s have been surmounted. The newly emerging fields of derived algebraic geometry and higher algebra are a direct consequence.

The research carried out over the course of this award has been devoted to developing and analyzing the theory of these structured ring spectra, with a heavy emphasis on developing effective tools for their construction. This resulted in work with Gepner that gave effective tools for the classification of Galois extensions in the sense of Rognes on such objects; work with Hopkins on understandinghow a central example (the complex cobordism spectrum) can map to others; work with Lipshitz and Sarkar on applications of them to knot theory and homotopy-theoretic incarnations of the Jones polynomial; work with Barwick on understanding the algebraic K-theory of several prominent such examples; work with Angeltveit-Blumberg-Gerhardt-Hill-Mandell on clarifying constructions of topological Hochschild homology and topological cyclic homology; and work with Hill on extending the theory of topological modular forms to cover modular forms with level structure.
